data.title: [3.0] TestCube can't be placed where it should
data.body:
Tested on Godot 3.0 af282b56feb8d84049f911dd1d91d82bd2211727
Windows 10 64 bits, nVidia GeForce 940M

I made a scene with 7 TestCubes, but one of them just doesn't want to show where it should.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1311555/24583875/afcba24c-1759-11e7-9bbb-e3d27ed22104.png)

Reproduction steps:

1) Open this scene: [cube_doesnt_show.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/888140/cube_doesnt_show.zip).
Notice TestCube2 is at the same place as TestCube1, at (-20, 0, 20)
1) Move TestCube2 at (20, 0, -20)
2) Save and close the scene
3) Reopen it: notice the cube teleported back to where it was before

The console output mentions a script error as soon as I translate the cube, although there is no script in the scene. There was one in the screenshot before I find this odd behaviour, but I removed it since:

```
ERROR: Script inherits from native type 'Reference', so it can't be instanced in object of type: 'PropertyValueEvaluator'
   At: modules\gdscript\gd_script.cpp:394
ERROR: Script inherits from native type 'Reference', so it can't be instanced in object of type: 'PropertyValueEvaluator'
   At: modules\gdscript\gd_script.cpp:394
ERROR: Script inherits from native type 'Reference', so it can't be instanced in object of type: 'PropertyValueEvaluator'
   At: modules\gdscript\gd_script.cpp:394
```

data.title: [3.0] Memory leak in Mesh.add_surface_from_arrays()
data.body:
Tested on Godot 3.0 af282b56feb8d84049f911dd1d91d82bd2211727
Windows 10 64 bits

The following script shows a memory leak:

```gdscript
extends Node


func _process(delta):
	var mesh = Mesh.new()
	var arrays = [
		[Vector3(0,0,0)],
		null,
		null,
		null,
		null,
		null,
		null,
		null,
		null
	]
	mesh.add_surface_from_arrays(Mesh.PRIMITIVE_POINTS, arrays)

	get_node("Label").set_text(str(OS.get_dynamic_memory_usage()))
```

The memory doesn't increase if I remove `add_surface_from_arrays`.

I found it because it has a massive impact on my voxel game, where meshes are generated at runtime, 1 Mb is leaked at each chunk update.

data.title: Cannot create and send mouse clicks to viewport
data.body:
The docs [advise](http://docs.godotengine.org/en/stable/tutorials/engine/inputevent.html) a little bit of code that looks like:

>var ev = InputEvent()
>ev.type = InputEvent.MOUSE_BUTTON
>ev.button_index = BUTTON_LEFT

Well, just try it! Use cases might include something like [this](https://github.com/fluffrabbit/TestVRGUI). Imagine playing Marathon (you know, the game where you have to read a bunch of shit) with all the glory of Godot's BBcode support, clicking links and such, in virtual reality! Problem is, I'm not sure if those links can be clicked because in VR one does not use a mouse. One does not simply *mouse* into VR.

I modified the GUI in 3D example to continuously send mouse clicks inside the _on_area_input event, rather than just *whatever* you *actually* do with the mouse. On the Web, which those fruitcakes at Mozilla seem to be pushing for, you can send a click event and you can do this or that to your heart's content because it's for babies, but Godot's GUI system is really stripped down. Holy shit, why even use it? I kid, I kid. It's April Fools' Day so I think I'm entitled to a little verbal kickboxing. So when you comment out line 33, suddenly no trabaja.

Anyways, I hope I'm getting the point across. Need to generate MOUSE_BUTTON event from scratch in order to replace mouse with (for instance) key, cannot do so, angry. Above mentioned modified GUI in 3D example attached below.

[broken_gui_in_3d.zip](https://github.com/fluffrabbit/TestVRGUI/blob/master/broken_gui_in_3d.zip?raw=true)

EDIT: Sorry, these fonts are TINY. If you have trouble reading it you can send me an email @ AOL and I'll send it to you in big fonts.

It uses this library: https://github.com/Zylann/godot_opensimplex but i don't think it is a problem of the library.
here is the problem that occurs:
https://gfycat.com/NegativeValuableBaleenwhale
Seems like it only occurs when the number goes more than a specific number, when testing, the number for me and someone else was different but at 100*100 we both had this problem.
Why is this happening?
Thank you.

data.title: "Play" shortcut variation that doesn't restart project
data.body:
It's not currently possible to bind shortcuts in a way that mimics Visual Studio's F5 behavior, where the key launches the project if it's inactive and continues the code debugger if it's active because the "Play" shortcut remains active while the project is running, and using it restarts the project.  It also takes priority over "Continue" if the two are bound to the same key.

This could be improved by adding a separate shortcut that plays the project if it's not running, and does nothing if it is running.  Maybe rename "Play" to "Restart" or "Play/Restart" and name the new option "Play?"

data.title: Script editor crash with quotation mark
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Arch Linux with godot 3.0 Pre-release


**Issue description:**
Using character " or quotation mark results in crash when not entered in function such as under the extends command.

Crash won't happen if quotation mark is inside a comment.
Apostrophe also causes crash.
Also crash won't happen if there tab before apostrophe or quotation mark.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Open script editor and type quotation mark in anywhere that is not in function

data.title: Make GDScript allow some keywords as identifiers
data.body:
Fixes #8085

Here is a test script:
```gdscript
extends SceneTree

func log(a): # Call with self.log()
	print(a)

func _initialize():
	var dict = {
		"true": 1,
		"false": 1,
		"null": 1,
		"sync": 1,
		"remote": 1,
		"slave": 1,
		"if": 1,
		"match": 1,
	}

	print(dict.true)
	print(dict.false)
	print(dict.null)
	print(dict.sync)
	print(dict.remote)
	print(dict.slave)
	print(dict.if)
	print(dict.match)
	print(log(1))
	print(self.log(1))
	quit()
```

Here are some things that won't work with this changes:
```gdscript
var var = 1
var const = 1
var func = 1

func and(a, b): # Technical issues for this one, since it is equivalent to func &&(a, b):..
```
And here are some strange ones that would work
```gdscript
func var(): pass # Call with self.var()
func func(): pass # self.func() or just func() if lambda isn't merged
class class:
  static func static(): return true
func _ready():
  self.var()
  self.func()
  print(class.static()) # true
```

data.title: Seperate octree layers for visual instances.
data.body:
This changes the way the VisualServerScene organises instances by actually placing them on separate layers with their own octrees. This is a significant optimization specifically for this PR (https://github.com/godotengine/godot/pull/8215) since you'll want to use this to mask certain objects on certain cameras, but cameras would be forced to traverse one massive octree regardless of what objects are important with the original. Now, a camera will only have to traverse and cull the layers specific to it. As a scenario, imagine you have two cameras for an FPS, one for the player's view (which would require traversing many objects), and one for the gun viewmodel, which only cares about one object. This removes the overhead of the gun camera having to traverse the entire octree. It does however operate under the assumption that the majority of VisualInstance will mostly be confined to one layer at a time, which is what most scenarios should only require.

There may be alternative techniques (and the culling system could probably do with a broader overhaul anyway), but this is the technique I've been using at it seems to work fine.

data.title: Support for multiple cameras per viewport.
data.body: Feature I spoke briefly with @reduz about including for the new renderer, although I've had this feature in my own branch for a while. It basically allows you to have multiple active 3D cameras for a single viewport which can be rendered one after another in an order specified by the new 'depth' parameter. By using this, you can create a variety of effects such as a first-person-shooter gun model which receives correct lighting but doesn't intersect with other geometry and can even have it's own independent FOV, or a mesh-based skybox rendered before everything else. The changes are fairly benign, but the multiple cameras can incur significant overhead in certain situations due to the way the VisualServerScene organises instances. To overcome this, I propose using the changes from this PR (https://github.com/godotengine/godot/pull/8216).

data.title: Made slide and reflect active verbs acting on itself in Vector2 and V…
data.body:
…ector3.

This is in alignment with other functions in vector classes.
Also added checks for normalization, fixed the sign of reflect (which now corresponds to reflection along a plane mathematically), added bounce method and updated docs.

Fixes #8201.

data.title: Remove Patch9Frame
data.body: Patch9Frame and a Panel with a StyleBoxTexture are effectively the same thing, so I think it should be removed since they're the same thing. I find it redundant to have two things that do the same thing, and only makes maintaining them more of a hassle.

data.title: Bi-directional Visual to Text: an other paradigm to write code.
data.body:
**Problem 1**
I can add the "camera2D" functionality in the character, for example, just by attaching a Node to the character.

I also can create a "playerMove" node, for example, and never again rewrite this code, nor locate in an external place how to do this. 

However, the process of creating a node requires configuration files, external icons and this is done outside the Engine.
http://docs.godotengine.org/en/stable/tutorials/making_plugins.html

**Problem 2**
A "page of code" is like a book without sumary. You do not know what's inside without opening and searching. And even worse when the programmers no insert comments. 

**Problem 3**
When I add the node "camera2D", for example, I do not have access to the contents of this node. It is a black box. The implementation is done in a traditional way, outside the Engine.

---------

This is the current reality
![001](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9745229/24685036/4ff39b0c-1981-11e7-81e2-8c3e62fd62b9.png)

This is other possibility
![002](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9745229/24685043/5c914f62-1981-11e7-8812-bf893727b8a6.png)

Once that the user can easily create and edit nodes the productivity increases about 10x. Because, using nodes in this way is like create behaviors in Stencyl. This only changes the name: node to behavior. Lastly, the index for navigation of example above, It's no different from how everything is done within Godot. 

Visual programming is great for sort and organize.
And writing programming is great for copying, pasting and editing.
So we have the best of both worlds.

What ultimately matters is more organization, more productivity, more quality and more result. And how this all can or will be improved, I have presented something to consider.

data.title: Honor the Tween's final values
data.body: Make sure the Tween's final values are respected. Fixes issue #6565.

data.title: Add missing binding for DUPLICATE_USE_INSTANCING
Add Attach and Clear Script buttons (2.1)
data.body:
I'm "cherry picking" these features because I missed them when migrating to 2.1 from 2.2-legacy (I noticed this because of [this post on facebook group](https://www.facebook.com/groups/godotengine/permalink/981991981937396/)).

I had to do these changes manually because the structure of 2.1 (and master) is different from 2.2 (eg: 2.1 and master has no `/tools` folder).

I made the commits separately for easier testing and revision ^^

data.title: Vector math reflect() function is wrong?
Update classes.xml to master version, add a small feature to doc_status
Fix polar decomposition in 2D.
data.body:
When performing polar decomposition in 2D as B = R.S, where R is rotation (with determinant +1) and S is scaling, use the convention that reflections are absorbed into S through a reflection around y axis.
In 3D, this is done by using a reflection along all three axes, but since the dimensionality is even in 2D, one axis needs to be chosen.

Fixes Matrix32::get_rotation and Matrix32::get_scale (which weren't properly fixed in #7445).

data.title: (3.0) editor control move doesn't affect rect_pos(ition)
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Ubuntu 16.04, GoDot master 3.0

**Issue description:**
Dragging a control in the editor doesn't affect rect_pos(ition), but if you click on the value opened inputs are updated.

**Steps to reproduce:**
- open editor
- add any control element (e.g. Label)
- drag it
- observe no change in rect.pos properties (defect)
- click on Pos values, they are updated (good)
